messageBody:
First, I agree with everything that Mike Clark and J.B. said. :-) But, I do want to add my 1/50th of a Federal Reserve Note concerning using JUnit on a large project.

I am the technical lead for a large project here at Lands' End. (How do I define a large project? If it goes wrong, then two VP's get very upset and tens of thousands of customers are affected ... that's large in my book.) We use JUnit for unit tests and to drive both functional and load tests (a little pragmatic automation in action! :-)

Here are my thoughts on the pros and cons of using unit tests:

cons:

1. You actually have to write unit test code.
2. You have to maintain unit test code.

pros:

Too many to list here. Just spend about two minutes googling or surfing junit.org and you'll get a bunch.

I think that if I could say only one thing about unit testing that people would remember, it would be this: "Unit testing is the first toll booth on the road to software quality." (You may refer to this as Chappell's third law of Software Development). While I'd be the first to say that there is more to software quality than unit testing, unit testing is the gateway to software quality. If you don't unit test, then it's either unlikely that you are doing the other requirements for software quality or you are trying to do them and they're failing because your basic building blocks (your testable units of software) are poorly written.

I could write more, but that was the main point I wanted to make that wasn't already covered by the other excellent responses.

Simon

>

>Hi - I'm attempting to introduce junit testing techniques into
>where I work.
>So far I've used it on a small scale, writing junit tests for
>enhancement
>changes to existing code.
>We have some large projects, along the lines of web booking engines for
>travel agents, that already exist. One of the concerns that I (and
>developers) have is that we will end up with thousands of test
>cases, many
>of which will involve using substantial amounts of MockObjects
>to set up
>test cases and that all this will become too much of an
>overhead to manage &
>maintain. Specifically, that changing code in the future will involve
>analysis of not only the project code but also the junit test code - an
>overhead we don't have today of course.
>
>Has anyone applied junit on a large scale such as this? I'd
>love to hear
>comments about pros & cons and lessons learned etc.
>
>Rgds,
>Kevin.
